bibl.title: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Lawrence Reed, February 28, 1941

div1.p: Kellogg informs Lawrence Reed that he will receive copies of the first two paintings in the series "Pioneers of American Medicine." He requests to meet with Lawrence Reed.

div1.head: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Lawrence Reed, February 28, 1941
div1.opener:
DR' HENCH
EXECUTIVE
February 28, 1941.
General Walter L. Reed
2810 Thirty-Sixth Place, N.W.
Washington, D.C.
Dear General Reed:
div1.p:
Under separate cover I have just mailed you copies of the first two
paintings in the series “Pioneers of American Medicine” by Dean Corn-
well. This series as you may know is being sponsored by John Wyeth
& Brother Inc. of Philadelphia and the next subject is to be titled
“The Conquest of Yellow Fever”. Mr. Cornwell and I had done what we
thought was a fairly good job of research until we recently had a
letter from Dr. Philip F. Hench of the Mayo Clinic who invited us to
see him a couple of weeks ago. While Mr. Cornwell was unable to go,
Dr. Hench gave an associate of mine and myself what we consider the
real low down on the yellow fever story.

At the moment I do not have any specific questions to ask you, but I
feel that you might be interested in knowing that such a project is
underway and hope that should I find it necessary to write you for
any additional information you will be willing to cooperate as far as
it is convenient. We have talked with General Kean but at the time
I did not know as much about General Kean's background in connection
with the study made of yellow fever as I do today. It is my intention
to be in Washington this coming Wednesday and at that time I may
take the liberty of calling you on the phone and asking for an
appointment.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, George A. Kellogg
Advertising Director
John Wyeth & Brother Inc. GAK/ecs
